description: Common issues encountered across builds with proven solutions

patterns.title: Third-Party Sites Blocking Iframe Embedding with X-Frame-Options

issue.description: Third-party websites block iframe embedding using X-Frame-Options: DENY/SAMEORIGIN or Content-Security-Policy frame-ancestors headers
issue.error_message: To protect your security, [site] will not allow Firefox to display the page if another site has embedded it
symptoms: Browser error about security preventing iframe display
Blank iframes showing no content
Console errors: 'Refused to display [url] in a frame because it set X-Frame-Options to DENY'
Works in development with direct URLs but fails when embedded
80%+ of iframe content sources non-functional

patterns.root_cause: External websites use X-Frame-Options and CSP headers to prevent clickjacking attacks. Browser enforces these headers and blocks iframe rendering. Affects sites like skylinewebcams.com, earthcam.com, webcamtaxi.com, and most commercial webcam services.

scout.action: Detect iframe-based content aggregation and warn about embedding restrictions
scout.check: If project description mentions 'aggregating', 'embedding', 'iframes', or 'multiple sources', flag X-Frame-Options risk
questions: Will you be embedding third-party websites in iframes?
Do you control the content sources or are they external?
Have you verified these sites allow iframe embedding?
scout.recommendation: Suggest proxy solution architecture from the start

architect.action: Include proxy API route in architecture for iframe-heavy apps
specifics: Plan URL validation in seed scripts
Separate architecture for image URLs vs HTML pages
Include cache strategy (recommended: 60s for real-time feeds)

example.architecture_section: Proxy Pattern: Next.js API route fetches external content server-side, strips X-Frame-Options/CSP headers, rewrites relative URLs to absolute, returns embeddable content

conditions: If external sources are from different domains
If user confirms embedding third-party sites

builder.action: Implement proxy route and smart rendering component
files_to_create: Component with URL type detection (image vs HTML)
Conditional rendering: for images, proxied

implementation_details.proxy_route: Fetch with User-Agent header, strip X-Frame-Options/CSP, rewrite relative URLs, cache 60s
implementation_details.component_logic: Detect .jpg/.png extensions → use , else use

builder.seed_script_enhancement: Add URL validation: check X-Frame-Options header before adding to database

test.action: Verify iframe content loads from external sources
tests: Unit: Test URL detection logic (image vs HTML)
Integration: Test proxy route returns content without X-Frame-Options header
E2E: Playwright test that validates iframe content is visible: await expect(page.frameLocator('iframe').first()).toBeVisible()
Manual: Check 5-10 random external sources in actual browser

conditions: >5 external URLs detected in seed data
External URLs are not from controlled domains
actions: Scout: Add X-Frame-Options warning to scout-report.md
Architect: Include proxy pattern in architecture
Test: Add E2E iframe visibility test
prevention.reason: Some projects may legitimately embed only friendly sources. Auto-apply only if clear iframe aggregation pattern detected.

patterns.impact: Critical - 80%+ of content sources non-functional. App appears broken to users. Core functionality fails.
patterns.fix_time_estimate: 45 minutes post-deployment, 10 minutes if included from start
affected_sites: Many news sites, social media embeds, third-party tools
workarounds: Use official embed APIs where available (e.g., YouTube, Twitter)
Use screenshot services for non-embeddable content
Request iframe-friendly URLs from content providers
patterns.legal_considerations: Proxying content may violate Terms of Service of some sites. Check ToS before implementing. Some sites have explicit anti-scraping clauses.
patterns.performance_notes: Proxy adds 500-1500ms latency on first load. Cache aggressively (60s) for real-time feeds, longer for static content. Monitor server bandwidth.
patterns.success_rate: 95% with proxy solution (some sites have additional bot protection)

detection_history.fix_applied: Next.js API proxy with header stripping

patterns.title: CORS Error with ES6 Modules from file://

issue.description: Browser blocks ES6 module imports from file:// protocol
issue.error_message: Origin null is not allowed by Access-Control-Allow-Origin
symptoms: Game/app stuck at loading screen
Console error: Failed to load resource
Module imports fail silently

patterns.root_cause: Browsers enforce CORS policy that blocks ES6 module loading from file:// for security. Unit tests with Jest+jsdom don't catch this because they mock the browser environment.

scout.check: If project uses ES6 modules AND targets browser, warn about file:// restrictions
scout.note: Recommend dev server from the start

specifics: Create npm run dev script with auto-open

builder.verification: Builder should create package.json with dev server configured

test.action: Verify dev server starts and modules load
tests: Check dev server package exists in package.json
Verify npm scripts include dev/start
Test server starts without errors
Validate modules load via HTTP (if browser testing available)
test.integration_test: If Playwright/Selenium available, test actual browser loading

patterns.impact: Critical - Breaks entire application. Users cannot run the app at all.
patterns.success_rate: 100% when dev server included from start

prevention_history.result: Zero CORS errors, perfect ES6 module loading

patterns.title: AWS CDK Inline Lambda Handler Name Mismatch

issue.description: CDK Lambda function created with inline code uses filename 'index.py' but handler configuration specifies 'handler.lambda_handler', causing ImportModuleError
issue.error_message: Runtime.ImportModuleError: Unable to import module 'handler': No module named 'handler'
symptoms: Lambda returns 'Internal server error' on invocation
CloudWatch logs show: Unable to import module 'handler'
Function handler configured as 'handler.lambda_handler' but code is in 'index.py'
CDK deployment succeeds but function fails at runtime
Issue not caught during CDK synth or deploy phases

patterns.root_cause: When using lambda.Code.fromInline() in AWS CDK, the code is packaged into a file named 'index.py' by default, but the handler property must be updated to match ('index.lambda_handler' instead of 'handler.lambda_handler'). This mismatch is not detected during CDK synthesis or deployment.

scout.action: Identify AWS Lambda deployments and flag inline code handler risks
scout.check: If project uses AWS CDK with Lambda functions, warn about handler naming conventions
scout.recommendation: Always use lambda.Code.fromAsset() for production or ensure handler matches inline code filename

architect.action: Design Lambda functions with correct handler configuration
specifics: For inline code: handler must be 'index.lambda_handler'
For asset code: handler should match actual filename (e.g., 'handler.lambda_handler' if file is handler.py)
Document handler naming convention in architecture
Consider using separate Lambda directory structure instead of inline code for complex functions

builder.action: Create Lambda functions with matching handler configuration

implementation_details.asset_code: Match handler to actual Python filename in directory
implementation_details.verification: Add comment explaining handler naming convention

builder.fix_for_existing: Update handler to 'index.lambda_handler' using: aws lambda update-function-configuration --function-name <name> --handler index.lambda_handler

test.action: Verify Lambda functions can be invoked successfully
tests: Deploy Lambda function to AWS
Invoke function with test payload: aws lambda invoke --function-name <name> out.json
Check for ImportModuleError in CloudWatch logs
Test via API Gateway or other trigger if applicable

actions: Scout: Warn about handler naming in scout-report.md
Builder: Use 'index.lambda_handler' for all inline Lambda code
Test: Add Lambda invocation test to verify import success

patterns.impact: Critical - Lambda function completely non-functional. All API endpoints return 500 errors. Zero functionality until fixed.

detection_history.root_cause_analysis: CDK creates index.py from inline code but handler was set to handler.lambda_handler

patterns.title: API Gateway Path Routing Logic Precedence Issue

issue.description: Lambda function routing logic checks generic path patterns (startsWith) before specific paths, causing specific endpoints to return 404
symptoms: GET /builds returns 404 'Not found'
GET /build/{id} works correctly
Path logic checks '/build/' before '/builds'
Specific paths are never reached due to greedy pattern matching
Issue only affects certain path combinations

patterns.root_cause: Lambda handler routing logic uses if/elif chain that checks generic patterns (path.startswith('/build/')) before specific exact matches (path == '/builds'). The generic pattern matches first and the specific path is never evaluated.

scout.action: Identify REST API implementations and flag routing complexity
scout.check: If project involves API Gateway with multiple endpoints, warn about routing precedence
scout.recommendation: Design API paths to avoid ambiguous patterns (e.g., use /build/list instead of /builds if /build/{id} exists)

architect.action: Design API path structure with clear precedence
specifics: Document routing precedence: exact matches first, then pattern matches
Plan for Lambda proxy integration routing logic
best_practices: Check exact matches before startsWith patterns
Order if/elif from most specific to least specific

builder.action: Implement routing logic with correct precedence

implementation_details.example_code:
if path == '/builds' and method == 'GET': return list_builds()
elif path.startswith('/build/') and method == 'GET': return get_build()

builder.anti_pattern:
if path.startswith('/build/'): ...
elif path == '/builds': ... # Never reached!

test.action: Test all API endpoints including edge cases
tests: Test exact path matches: GET /builds
Test pattern matches: GET /build/123
Test similar paths: /build, /builds, /build/
Verify routing logic order in code review
Add integration tests for all endpoints

conditions: project uses API Gateway with Lambda proxy integration
multiple endpoints with similar path patterns
actions: Builder: Always check exact matches before patterns

patterns.impact: Medium - Specific endpoints non-functional, but workarounds exist. Affects user experience but not catastrophic.

detection_history.evidence: CDK stack redeployment with corrected routing logic

patterns.title: AWS Bedrock Agent Defaults to SUPERVISOR Collaboration Mode

issue.description: Bedrock Agent cannot be prepared because AgentCollaboration is set to SUPERVISOR mode but no collaborators are configured
issue.error_message: ValidationException: This agent cannot be prepared. The AgentCollaboration attribute is set to SUPERVISOR but no agent collaborators are added.
symptoms: Agent creation succeeds but 'Prepare' button fails
Error mentions SUPERVISOR mode and missing collaborators
Agent status stuck at NOT_PREPARED
Cannot create aliases until agent is prepared
Issue occurs even for single-agent configurations

patterns.root_cause: AWS Bedrock Agent console may default to SUPERVISOR collaboration mode (multi-agent orchestration) even when user wants a single agent with action groups. SUPERVISOR mode requires defining sub-agents, but standard single-agent use cases should have collaboration disabled.

scout.action: Clarify agent architecture: single agent vs multi-agent collaboration
questions: Will this be a single agent with action groups, or a supervisor orchestrating multiple agents?
Do you need multi-agent collaboration features?
Is this a standard agent workflow or complex agent orchestration?
scout.recommendation: Default to single-agent with action groups unless explicitly multi-agent

specifics: Document: Single agent with N action groups (most common)
OR: Supervisor agent coordinating N sub-agents (advanced)
Specify collaboration mode: DISABLED for single agent, SUPERVISOR for multi-agent
Note: CDK cannot fully configure Bedrock Agents, manual console setup required

agent_types.single_agent_action_groups: Collaboration: DISABLED. Agent directly invokes Lambda action groups.
agent_types.multi_agent_supervisor: Collaboration: SUPERVISOR. Agent delegates to sub-agents.

builder.action: Document manual Bedrock Agent setup steps
manual_steps: Configure action groups (Scout, Architect, Builder, Tester)
If SUPERVISOR mode is set, disable it: Edit Agent → Agent Collaboration → Disable
Save Agent ID and Alias ID for Lambda configuration
builder.note: CDK L2 constructs for Bedrock Agents are limited. Use L1 CfnAgent if available, otherwise manual setup required.

test.action: Verify agent can be prepared and invoked
tests: Agent status changes to PREPARED
Alias creation succeeds
Test agent in Bedrock console with sample prompts
Verify action groups are invoked correctly
Check Lambda logs for action group invocations

actions: Scout: Clarify single vs multi-agent in requirements
Builder: Include agent setup checklist with collaboration mode step
Documentation: Add troubleshooting section for SUPERVISOR mode error
prevention.reason: Bedrock Agent configuration is primarily manual in AWS Console. Auto-detection not feasible.

patterns.impact: High - Blocks agent deployment. Cannot test or use agent until resolved. Causes deployment delays.
patterns.workaround: Edit agent in Bedrock console → Find Agent Collaboration or Multi-Agent Collaboration section → Disable/turn off collaboration → Save → Prepare agent

detection_history.detected_by: Manual agent preparation in AWS Console
detection_history.fix_applied: Disabled agent collaboration mode in console settings
detection_history.notes: Agent had 4 action groups (Scout, Architect, Builder, Tester) but collaboration mode was enabled by default

patterns.additional_notes: This is a UX issue in AWS Bedrock console. The default behavior may change over time. Always verify collaboration settings match intended architecture (single-agent vs multi-agent).
